title: SQL DB User and PW
Password for Cowis.Net Backoffice User  look up - User lost password
text: Man meldet sich als Cowsys User an Cowis an und geht dann z.B. in den Bereich Artikel Dort ruft man über Extras -> SQL Befehl ausführen auf Mit diesem Befehl kann man Benutzer und Kennwörter aus der Cowis DB auslesen select [FldAgBeDtUser], [FldAgBeDtBemerkung], [FldAgBeDtPasswort] from [dbo].[T980_AgBenutzer] eingrenzen kann man es mit der Benutzer Eingabe select [FldAgBeDtUser], [FldAgBeDtBemerkung], [FldAgBeDtPasswort] from [dbo].[T980_AgBenutzer] where FldAgBeDtUser ='Lara' (Lara ist dann durch den Benutzernamen zu ersetzen) Dann wird nur das Passwort des Users angezeigt
description:
Man meldet sich als Cowsys User an Cowis an und geht dann z.B. in den Bereich Artikel 
Dort ruft man über Extras -> SQL Befehl ausführen auf 
 

 

Mit diesem Befehl kann man Benutzer und Kennwörter aus der Cowis DB auslesen 

 
  select [FldAgBeDtUser], [FldAgBeDtBemerkung], [FldAgBeDtPasswort] from [dbo].[T980_AgBenutzer] 
 
eingrenzen kann man es mit der Benutzer Eingabe 
select [FldAgBeDtUser], [FldAgBeDtBemerkung], [FldAgBeDtPasswort] from [dbo].[T980_AgBenutzer] where FldAgBeDtUser ='Lara'
(Lara ist dann durch den Benutzernamen zu ersetzen) 

Dann wird nur das Passwort des Users angezeigt

title: Customer “destroyed” the quick filter menu
text: There are so-called quick filters in the Cowis.Net back office, e.g. in the cash statements (see screenshot) These filters are either suitable for free input (as in the article area under the description) or can ONLY be used as a drop-down, as in the cash accounts area (branch). If the user enters e.g. branches separated by commas in a drop-down area (screenshot), then the user can do this, but this means that the program item (in this case cash register closings) can no longer be accessed by the logged in user (ticket #42749). If you log in as another user you can open the program item. The problem is that Cowis.Net saves the wrong menu entry in the database. The problem can be solved as follows. You log in to Cowis:Net Backoffice with the Cowsys administrator user Cash accounts Extras Execute SQL command inserts this SQL command update T977_AgFilterZL set FldAgFzDtBedinung1 = '' where FldAgFzDtBedinung1 like '%,%' and FldAgFzDtRaum='Nr500_KaTagesabschluesse' Click execute and the problem is solved
description:
There are so-called quick filters in the Cowis.Net back office, e.g. in the cash statements (see screenshot)

These filters are either suitable for free input (as in the article area under the description) or can ONLY be used as a drop-down, as in the cash accounts area (branch).


If the user enters e.g. branches separated by commas in a drop-down area (screenshot), then the user can do this, but this means that the program item (in this case cash register closings) can no longer be accessed by the logged in user (ticket #42749). If you log in as another user you can open the program item.






The problem is that Cowis.Net saves the wrong menu entry in the database.


The problem can be solved as follows.


You log in to Cowis:Net Backoffice with the Cowsys administrator user

Cash accounts

Extras

Execute SQL command

inserts this SQL command


update T977_AgFilterZL set FldAgFzDtBedinung1 = '' where FldAgFzDtBedinung1 like '%,%' and FldAgFzDtRaum='Nr500_KaTagesabschluesse'


Click execute

and the problem is solved

title: How to create users automatically in SQL Server
text: The SA user is always set up with the Cowis standard password (sapwd). In order to have the required users "Cowis", Cowislesen" "Cowiskasse" created by Cowis.Net or Cowiskasse, it is important that NO database (Cowis or Cowiskasse) is in the data directory. By calling "C:\cowis\cowiskasse\cowiskasse.exe /BDB" A completely new Cowiskasse database is created and the users are created in the SQL server.
description:
The SA user is always set up with the Cowis standard password (sapwd).


In order to have the required users "Cowis", Cowislesen" "Cowiskasse" created by Cowis.Net or Cowiskasse, it is important that NO database (Cowis or Cowiskasse) is in the data directory.


By calling "C:\cowis\cowiskasse\cowiskasse.exe /BDB"

A completely new Cowiskasse database is created and the users are created in the SQL server.

title: Database (Cowis / Cowiskasse) is defective, what can you do in repair mode
text: Acute case with a customer: The Cowiskasse did not want to read a package and always aborted it. At the time of the cancellation, this (or a similar) message appears in the Windows event viewer: "SQL Server encountered a logical consistency-based I/O error: Incorrect checksum (expected: 0x9b5fe079; actual: 0x307ad2ed). The error is while reading page (1:9772) in database with ID 5 at offset 0x00000004c58000 in file 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL12.COWIS\MSSQL\DATA\alt\CowisKasse.mdf' occurred. For more information, see other error messages in the SQL Server error log or system event log. This is a serious error that threatens database integrity and must be addressed immediately. Run a full database consistency check (DBCC CHECKDB). This error can be caused by many factors. For more information, see SQL Server Books Online." You log in to the SQL Server Management Studio (with SA user) You can then execute these queries one after the other You can then execute these queries one after the other These queries (instructions) also work for the Cowis.Net back office database. Depending on the database, you have to use the DB name COWIS or COWISKASSE ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET EMERGENCY DBCC checkdb([cowis]) ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE DBCC CheckDB ([cowis], REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS) ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET MULTI_USER
description:
Acute case with a customer:

The Cowiskasse did not want to read a package and always aborted it.



At the time of the cancellation, this (or a similar) message appears in the Windows event viewer:
"SQL Server encountered a logical consistency-based I/O error: Incorrect checksum (expected: 0x9b5fe079; actual: 0x307ad2ed). The error is while reading page (1:9772) in database with ID 5 at offset 0x00000004c58000 in file 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\MSSQL12.COWIS\MSSQL\DATA\alt\CowisKasse.mdf' occurred. For more information, see other error messages in the SQL Server error log or system event log. This is a serious error that threatens database integrity and must be addressed immediately. Run a full database consistency check (DBCC CHECKDB). This error can be caused by many factors. For more information, see SQL Server Books Online."


You log in to the SQL Server Management Studio (with SA user)


You can then execute these queries one after the other


You can then execute these queries one after the other

These queries (instructions) also work for the Cowis.Net back office database.

Depending on the database, you have to use the DB name COWIS or COWISKASSE


ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET EMERGENCY

DBCC checkdb([cowis])

ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE

DBCC CheckDB ([cowis], REPAIR_ALLOW_DATA_LOSS)

ALTER DATABASE [cowis] SET MULTI_USER

title: Cash register closings can no longer be called up in the Cowis.Net back office
text: Customer reports that a certain Cowis user can no longer open the program item "Cash register closings". This is due to a specific user action that we are trying to prevent with the Cowis.Net back office version 6.4.60 from November 5th, 2024. What is the problem, or what did the user do: In the Cowis.Net back office version 6.4.60 up to November 5th, 2024, it was only possible to select (or filter) by branch in the cash register closings area using the drop-down menu This was the previous option for selection / filtering Now it sometimes happened that a user tried to list the branches separated by commas The result was that the user could no longer call up the cash register closings area. Cowis creates entries for these filters in the SQL database (in table 977). However, these commands cannot be called or executed by Cowis, which is why the "lockout" occurs. You have to log in as a COWSYS user in the Cowis.Net back office, then you can go to the cash register closings. There you call up the area for SQL execution via Tools -> Execute SQL command With a select command on table 977 you can see which entries are there, in which area they apply and which user is affected Here you can see that for the cash register closings area (or daily closings) there is an entry for the user "Chef" with the "selection" [1,2,4]. With this "clean command" you can cancel the entry for the branch selection. update T977_AgFilterZL set FldAgFzDtBedinung1 = '' where FldAgFzDtBedinung1 like '%,%' and FldAgFzDtBereich='Nr500_KaTagesabschluesse' The result is that the entry itself is still there, but the selection according to 1,2,4 has been removed. The user Chef can now access the cash register closings again. You exit Cowis once so that you are logged out as COWSYS and the case is closed !!If you don't know what you are doing, forward it to 2nd Line Support!!
description:
Customer reports that a certain Cowis user can no longer open the program item "Cash register closings".


This is due to a specific user action that we are trying to prevent with the Cowis.Net back office version 6.4.60 from November 5th, 2024.


What is the problem, or what did the user do:

In the Cowis.Net back office version 6.4.60 up to November 5th, 2024, it was only possible to select (or filter) by branch in the cash register closings area using the drop-down menu

This was the previous option for selection / filtering




Now it sometimes happened that a user tried to list the branches separated by commas


The result was that the user could no longer call up the cash register closings area.


Cowis creates entries for these filters in the SQL database (in table 977). However, these commands cannot be called or executed by Cowis, which is why the "lockout" occurs.



You have to log in as a COWSYS user in the Cowis.Net back office, then you can go to the cash register closings.

There you call up the area for SQL execution via


Tools -> Execute SQL command




With a select command on table 977 you can see which entries are there, in which area they apply and which user is affected




Here you can see that for the cash register closings area (or daily closings) there is an entry for the user "Chef" with the "selection" [1,2,4].



With this "clean command" you can cancel the entry for the branch selection.

update T977_AgFilterZL set FldAgFzDtBedinung1 = '' where FldAgFzDtBedinung1 like '%,%' and FldAgFzDtBereich='Nr500_KaTagesabschluesse'




The result is that the entry itself is still there, but the selection according to 1,2,4 has been removed.


The user Chef can now access the cash register closings again.


You exit Cowis once so that you are logged out as COWSYS and the case is closed


!!If you don't know what you are doing, forward it to 2nd Line Support!!

title: Cowiskasse does not start, an error message appears
text: Good to know: The Cowiskasse absolutely requires the so-called SQL server from Microsoft to be used. This is a program from Microsoft that manages all of your Cowiskasse data. The installation and setup is carried out by DdD. The SQL server usually always starts automatically and does not cause any problems. (You will notice the restriction) In certain situations it may happen that the SQL server has not yet started, but the Cowiskasse already wants to access it, in which case you will receive a message like this: You can now try to get the SQL server to start before the Cowiskasse needs it by restarting the cash register computer, or you can use this short "How do I help myself?" You need the local service operator of the Windows operating system: You click on the Windows start symbol (this can look like Windows 10, or be the well-known Windows 7 "ball"), you can also press the Windows symbol on your keyboard. Now you can simply type in the word "Services". (Basically you could also write "Dienste", but since there is a possibility that you have an English operating system, "Dienste" would not help you, whereas the German operating system can handle both "Dienste" and "Services".) The "tree" opens, which shows you the program with the highest match in the first place, this should be Dienste (or Services). You open this program by clicking on it A new window opens with the title "Services" (or Services) Now scroll with the scroll bar on the right until you get to the letter S There you look for an entry that contains the word "SQL Server". Usually followed by the word "COWIS" or "COWISKASSE", i.e. "SQL Server COWIS" or "SQL SERVER COWISKASSE". There will (most likely) be nothing in the "Status" column and "automatic" in the startup type column. This means that the SQL Server should "actually" start automatically but is not currently running. To start the SQL Server, click on the entry once with the left mouse button so that it is highlighted in blue. Now click on "start" in the top left corner In the best case, the status has changed to "running" and you can close the window and then start your Cowiskasse normally again.
description:
Good to know:

The Cowiskasse absolutely requires the so-called SQL server from Microsoft to be used.


This is a program from Microsoft that manages all of your Cowiskasse data. The installation and setup is carried out by DdD.


The SQL server usually always starts automatically and does not cause any problems. (You will notice the restriction)


In certain situations it may happen that the SQL server has not yet started, but the Cowiskasse already wants to access it, in which case you will receive a message like this:


You can now try to get the SQL server to start before the Cowiskasse needs it by restarting the cash register computer, or you can use this short "How do I help myself?"


You need the local service operator of the Windows operating system:

You click on the Windows start symbol (this can look like Windows 10, or be the well-known Windows 7 "ball"), you can also press the Windows symbol on your keyboard.


Now you can simply type in the word "Services".


(Basically you could also write "Dienste", but since there is a possibility that you have an English operating system, "Dienste" would not help you, whereas the German operating system can handle both "Dienste" and "Services".)


The "tree" opens, which shows you the program with the highest match in the first place, this should be Dienste (or Services).


You open this program by clicking on it



A new window opens with the title "Services" (or Services)



Now scroll with the scroll bar on the right until you get to the letter S



There you look for an entry that contains the word "SQL Server". Usually followed by the word "COWIS" or "COWISKASSE", i.e. "SQL Server COWIS" or "SQL SERVER COWISKASSE".



There will (most likely) be nothing in the "Status" column and "automatic" in the startup type column. This means that the SQL Server should "actually" start automatically but is not currently running.




To start the SQL Server, click on the entry once with the left mouse button so that it is highlighted in blue.


Now click on "start" in the top left corner





In the best case, the status has changed to "running" and you can close the window and then start your Cowiskasse normally again.
